results.title: Privacy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The State of the Nation Bounds of Freedom”.
A journalist comes across certain documents which could be embarrassing - or worse - to a public figure. Should he disclose the contents of these papers? Moderated by Arthur Miller.

group.title: The State of the Nation Bounds of Freedom

results.title: Prisoners of propaganda
results.brief_description: In 1943, the Imperial Japanese Army Secret Service forced a group of Australian servicemen to appear in a film to show the “exemplary” conditions under which Prisoners of War were treated by Japan. This program looks at the mysterious story behind that film, titled, Calling Australia.
results.description: In 1943, the Imperial Japanese Army Secret Service forced a group of Australian servicemen to appear in a film to show the “exemplary” conditions under which Prisoners of War were treated by Japan. results.title: Prisoners of incest
results.brief_description: Through the re-enactment, by actors, of a family group therapy session, this program documents the family trauma of incest. Members of the family meet together with a psychiatrist and a social worker to try and sort out their emotional reactions to their problem.
results.description: Through the re-enactment, by actors, of a family group therapy session, this program documents the family trauma of incest. Members of the family meet together with a psychiatrist and a social worker to try and sort out their emotional reactions to their problem.

results.title: Prisoners of debt: inside the global banking crisis
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Spotton, John Kramer, Peter Raymont and Robert Collison
results.brief_description: This fast-paced documentary tells the inside story of how Bank of Montreal chairman William Mulholland dealt with his bank’s debt-laden customers, Dome Petroleum and Mexico, during the summer of 1982, the summer the global debt crisis took the world by surprise. Interwoven with the Bank of Montreal’s story are interviews with well-known international bankers and financial experts who explain the causes of the debt crisis, confirm the extreme fragility of the international banking system, and outline the problems to be solved if the system is to survive.
results.title_for_label: Prisoners of debt: inside the global banking crisis

results.title: Prisoners of Conscience
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Everyman”.
The case histories of Gustavo Westerkamp and Danylo Shumuk who were imprisoned for their religious and political beliefs are examined and the work of Amnesty International

results.title: Prisoners of chance
results.creator_credit: Vitascope Productions, FilmFair Communications, Thom Eberhardt and Marc Stirdivant
results.brief_description: Presents dramatized re-enactments of three case studies of teenage pregnancies: a girl who gives up her baby for adoption when she realizes she cannot cope; a girl who lives with her parents after the birth; and a couple who marries after the girl becomes pregnant. De-romanticises the notion of “Having a baby” by pointing out some commo problems of teenage pregnancies.

results.title: Prisoners
results.creator_credit: Prisoners' Action Group, Tony Green and Mark Stiles
results.brief_description: Uses an innovative mix of interviews, photographs and sketches combined with comprehensive statistical information, to provide a profile on prisoners in New South Wales. Shows who goes to prison, why, and what happens to them inside the gaols. Interviews with ex-prisoners and their families demonstrate the futility of prisons as an answer to social problems. Touches on the destructive fires at Bathurst Jail and the reprisals carried out on prisoners before their transfer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Prisoners’ Action Group, Tony Green and Mark Stiles

results.title: Prisoner: the terrorist siege [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Reg Grundy Productions and Marie Trevor
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
Ep. 550 (dir. Steve Mann, wri. Fay Rousseaux): Prisoners and guards find themselves banded together when Wentworth is taken over by terrorists hired to release Bellinger. Police try to negotiate amidst the claim that hostages will be executed on the hour unless their demands are met. “Ep. 551” (dir. Chris Adshead, wri. James Simmonds): The women look to Top Dog Myra Desmond (Anne Phelan) for a plan but it eventuates that she is to choose the next victim. Bellinger learns she is to be taken out if they cannot escape and Reynolds calls in Special Operations when she learns of the ultimatum. “Ep. 552” (dir. Chris Adshead, wri. Coral Drouyn): Julie makes it to the phone and someone else is killed on the hour. The Freak is taken hostage as the terrorists make their escape. The women come to terms with their losses once the terrorists have departed. “Ep. 536” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Coral Drouyn): This bonus episode features flashbacks from previous episodes - Chrissie Latham’s attack on Frank, reminiscences of Warden Vera, The Freak plying Lizzie with liquor for information, Bea Smith coming down on Lyn Warner (Kerry Armstrong) then Max, and her final showdown with The Freak. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

results.title: Prisoner: the end [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Reg Grundy Productions and Marie Trevor
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
Ep. 600 (dir. Steve Mann, wri. Ian Smith): Top Dog Lou Kelly (Louise Siversen) takes control of the prison and unleashes a reign of bashings, execution and intimidation. The episode culminates in an orchestrated fight to the death between The Freak (Maggie Kirkpatrick) and Rita Connors (Glenda Linscott). “Ep. 601” (dir. Kendal Flanagan, wri. Alister Webb): The siege is over and there are repercussions for ringleader Lou. Will anyone break the prisoners code of silence? The search is on for a new Top Dog. “Ep. 691” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Quincy McQuade): Concludes the storyline of the relationship between supporting characters Kath and Merle. Rumours spread of Rita’s cancer as well as concern at her purported friendship with The Freak. “Ep. 692” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Marie Trevor, Ian Smith): In the climatic final episode Rita carries out the robbery planned in collaboration with The Freak. Retrieving the money appears hard though as Rita is captured and placed under close observation. Each section of episodes are introduced by Peter McTighe who explains what has transpired in the missing instalments. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

results.title: Prisoner: the early years [DVD]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
166 (dirs. Rod Hardy, Juliana Focht, prod. Philip East, wri. Alistair Sharp): Top Dog Bea Smith (Val Lehman) leads 6 of her fellow prisoners through an escape tunnel during a pantomime. Terror mounts when the tunnel collapses; there will be fatalities. There’s disgruntlement amongst prison staff regarding work conditions. “287” (dir: John McRae, prod. Ian Bradley, wri. John Mortimore): Enter “The Freak” (Maggie Kirkpatrick) with her trademark leather gloves in tow. Christine (Amanda Muggleton) is arrested while breaching parole, Lizzie (Sheila Florance) has a hangover and the search is on for a secret distillery in the prison. Burns (Collette Mann) plays bookie. “327” (dir. Juliana Focht, prod. John McRae, wri. Anne Lucas): The Freak uses intimidation when searching for her lost diaries. A deliberately lit fire finds The Freak and Smith trapped togther in the cells. The women are relocated to a men’s prison due to fire damage. “400” (dir. Mark DeFriest, prod. Lex Van Os, wri. Ian Smith): Hazel assists Jude to suicide and has to deal with the legal consequences of her actions. With assistance from The Freak, there’s moves for a new Top Dog following Smith’s abrupt departure. Cast includes Elspeth Ballantyne, Judith McGrath, Betty Bobbitt, Val Lehman, Amanda Muggleton and Jane Clifton. Introduced by Peter McTighe. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.
